With us on today's Roundtable are Joe Davidson, an editor for the Washington Post, Mary Frances Berry, professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania, and Nat Irvin, professor of future studies at Wake Forest University and a columnist for the Winston-Salem Journal.
All right, let's move on to topic number two.

You don't even have to have been a fan of sports or a fan of the NBA to have heard all of this hoorah this week about the former NBA player, John Amaechi, who has written a book and who has come out and announced that he is gay, and is the first, as far as we know, former NBA player to publicly announced his homosexuality.
Now, the reaction has been swift and it's been generally positive, but not always and some of it has been very mixed.
And in fact former NBA All Star Tim Hardaway may have given one of the reasons that Amaechi didn't come out before now.
Listen to what he had to say this week about having a gay teammate.
I hate gay people so, you know, I let it be known.
I don't like gay people.
I don't like to be around gay people.
I don't, you know, I'm homophobic.
I don't like it if - it shouldn't be in the world or the United States.
So yeah, I don't like it.
So now to be fair to Tim Hardaway, of course he has apologized for those comments, saying he shouldn't have said them.
Has he gone yet to treatment?
To therapy?
For his anger therapy management?
That will be coming.
And he won't be doing it in Las Vegas because NBA Commissioner David Stern, reacting to those comments, has removed Hardaway from any appearances in Las Vegas at the All-Star weekend this weekend.
Now, here's my question.
I want to talk - also let me just say also that Amaechi himself said at least Hardaway was honest in his remarks.
This has been all over sports talk radio like crazy.
And this is the second high-profile black man who has voiced anti-gay opinions publicly in the last few months.
And there is a feeling that has been expressed publicly again on talk radio and elsewhere that homophobia is very high, and in fact is higher in the black community than others.
So here's my question to you.
I'll come to you first, Joe.
Is this - homophobia - is this the prejudice that black folks have that no one wants to recognize?

Well, I think a lot of people do recognize it and a lot of people do talk about it, and I certainly hear a lot of comments about - within the black community, about how homophobic the black community is.
And I think there is certainly a high level, what I would consider, you know, too high a level of homophobia, bigotry, within the black community.
If it is in fact higher than in the white community, though, you know, I'm really not sure.

Because when you look at all of the laws and various things and societal pressures that have been put, that have been forced against members of the gay community, things that clearly have a bias against members of the gay community, most of those don't come in a structured and institutional way from black people.

Having said that, I do think that black people - and if that's the topic of our conversation - certainly from my point of view have a level of homophobia, bias, that is really unconscionable, particularly when you consider our history.

You know, Mary Frances, some people suggest that this is rooted, this homophobia, if you in fact agree with that characterization of it from our community's standpoint, that the root of some of this is the church.

Absolutely, and the EOC has just done a study that shows that male-on-male harassment of people because they think they're gay is on the rise, all the incidents of people doing stuff, locker-room type stuff and on-the-job kind of stuff, perceiving people are gay.
And this homophobia is reinforced in the church.

And one of the problems is, it interferes with the us not only in the sense that your moral sense it's outraged, but dealing with AIDS, for example, and the HIV crisis, all the homophobia, that's the whole down low thing related to that and black women, you know, getting infected and the like.
So we are killing ourselves.
And if you go to church, as I do, or if you listen to gospel music stations, as I do, you cannot miss sermons that reinforce all of the homophobia about sinners and this and this.

And it happens at the same time we're so dogged on illogical that we all know that if two kinds of people didn't go to church on Sunday, the black church would close - women, black women, and gay men.
If they didn't go, the church would close.
And sometimes it's a choir director and it's the preacher.
And yet this homophobia is persistently and consistently enforced.
And so Tim Hardaway was being ignorant.
He was expressing these beliefs that are reinforced throughout the community.
Not that white people, as Joe said, white people are homophobic too.
You can see it everywhere in the church.
But it's tragic with black people.
And it is time for him to go to get his therapy and come back out and say that he's change.
Personality rehab?
Yes.
Where do you see - Nat, where do you see this leading us?

I mean, are we going to be able, as a community, work our way through this and come to the other side, so to speak, or we just going to be stuck with this sense of homophobia because it is so connected to Christian beliefs in the black church?
Well, you know, the first thing that comes to mind, from a political standpoint, it is, and it is also moral as well - it is the issue of marriage.

That's where - when we deal with homophobia in one context from just a political and practical standpoint, that's where the church runs into its greatest hurdle, because we have such a strong bias against same sex marriage.
So that's the first thing.

But it terms of coming in contact - I mean the context of homophobia as it has been experience within the black experience, the black American experience, the African experience, there's no question we have made peace with it when it comes to singing in the choir, as Mary pointed out, the musicians.
We know this is a reality within our church experience.
Everybody has recognized gay people for the longest time.
